Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Spruce Beetle and Wildfire Interactions Under Varying Climate in the Rockies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will examine relationships between outbreaks of spruce bark beetles and wildfire activity in coniferous forests of the Rocky Mountains. Coincident with warmer temperatures, since the early 1990s synchronous outbreaks of native bark beetles have been occurring throughout coniferous forests of western North America from Alaska to the U.S. Southwest. Extensive tree mortality caused by bark beetle outbreaks is triggering major changes in forest landscapes and their associated ecosystem services. This collaborative research project will address the following questions about interactions between wildfire and spruce beetle outbreaks under varying climate and their consequences for ecosystem services: (1) How does climatic variation affect the initiation and spread of spruce beetle outbreaks across complex landscapes? (2) How does prior disturbance by windstorm, logging, and fire affect the subsequent occurrence and severity of spruce beetle outbreak? (3) In the context of a recently warmed climate, how do spruce beetle outbreaks affect forest structure and composition? (4) How do spruce beetle outbreaks affect fuels and potential wildfire activity under varying climatic conditions? (5) How will climate change and the climate-sensitive disturbances of wildfire and spruce beetle activity affect future ecosystem services in the subalpine zone of the southern Rocky Mountains under varying scenarios of adaptive forest management? The first four questions will be addressed through empirical research, including extensive tree-ring reconstructions of past disturbances, re-measurement of permanent forest plots, field measurements of effects of spruce beetle outbreaks on fuels, fire behavior modeling, and spatiotemporal analyses of the spread of recent spruce beetle outbreaks. The fifth question will be examined through simulation modeling of future forest conditions and their consequences for key selected ecosystem services, including biodiversity, wildlife habitat, and resilience to environmental change.

The project will contribute to understanding of fire-beetle interactions under varying climate conditions and their consequences for ecosystem services. The project will provide new information and insights about climate impacts on bark beetle outbreaks, feedbacks to and from wildfire and other disturbances, and sustaining ecosystem services. The project will provide current science information in support of forest management and decision making needs through evaluation of different adaptive management strategies to maintain biodiversity, wildlife habitat, and ecosystem resilience in the face of climate change. The project will develop pre-collegiate and collegiate-level curriculum material on wildfire and bark beetle interactions. It will create field and laboratory educational and training experiences for graduate and undergraduate students as well as an early-career postdoctoral researcher. To further enhance public education on fire-beetle topics, the project will produce a documentary video as well as a website of frequently asked questions about bark beetles and wildfire in the face of climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Severe and extensive bark beetle outbreaks have resulted in widespread tree mortality across the forests of western North America over the past thirty years. This has raised questions about the causal factors that trigger outbreaks and modulate their spread across complex landscapes.  This project examined the occurrence and spread of spruce beetle (Dendroctonus rufipennis) outbreaks in the subalpine forests of the U.S. Southern Rocky Mountains.

The research addressed the following three broad questions:

1. How does climatic variation affect the initiation and spread of spruce beetle outbreaks?

2. How does prior disturbance by previous spruce beetle outbreak affect the occurrence and severity of subsequent outbreaks?

3. How will climate change affect future forest conditions and the potential for spruce beetle outbreak.

We addressed the first question by reconstructing the history of spruce beetle outbreaks and climate from tree ring records over the period from 1650 to the present. Periods of outbreak coincided with both warmer temperatures and drought at time scales of one to several years. We addressed the second question by utilizing satellite imagery to map the progression of the severe spruce beetle outbreak over the period from 2000 to 2014. The results showed that the outbreak originated at several disjunct locations synchronously which implies that regional climate conditions (warmer, drier conditions) were the primary driver of the outbreak. There was a strong association of the spread of the beetle outbreak with reduced snow cover which is important in the context of earlier snow melt being observed across the Rocky Mountain region. The third question was examined through simulation modeling which incorporated the new empirical findings on the influences of both climate and forest attributes (mainly tree sizes reflecting previous disturbance by bark beetles) of the current project. The modeling results indicate that as temperatures continue to warm the resulting drier conditions will reduce the abundance of the host species (Engelmann spruce) so that its abundance will become limiting to future spruce beetle activity. Analogously, the decline in abundance of large trees due to the initial tree mortality due to increased spruce beetle activity associated with warmer and drier conditions will similarly constrain future spruce beetle activity. These negative feedbacks documented for spruce beetle are likely to also apply to other climatically sensitive beetle-conifer systems.

The broader impacts of the project included communication of these research findings to land managers and other stake holders through presentations at professional meetings and other public venues.  The clear demonstration that the spruce beetle outbreaks are driven primarily by warmer and drier climatic conditions is critically important to discusssions of societal adaptation to future changes in forest conditions. The broader impacts also included educational and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students as well as professional advancement of early career scientists through their involvement in the research and its dissemination to broad audiences.
